AM-GM, calculation

Compute the following limits and justify your calculations!

  1. lim⁡k→∞∫0kxn(1−xk)k dx\displaystyle \lim_{k\to\infty} \int_0^k x^n\p{1 - \frac{x}{k}}^k \,\diff{x}k→∞lim​∫0k​xn(1−kx​)kdx, where n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N.
  2. lim⁡k→∞∫0∞(1+xk)−kcos⁡(xk) dx\displaystyle \lim_{k\to\infty} \int_0^\infty \p{1 + \frac{x}{k}}^{-k} \cos\p{\frac{x}{k}} \,\diff{x}k→∞lim​∫0∞​(1+kx​)−kcos(kx​)dx.
Solution.

  1. Let fk(x)=(1−xk)kχ[0,k](x)f_k\p{x} = \p{1 - \frac{x}{k}}^k \chi_{\br{0,k}}\p{x}fk​(x)=(1−kx​)kχ[0,k]​(x). By AM-GM,

    (1⋅(1−xk)k)1/(k+1)≤1k+1(1+k⋅(1−xk))=1−xk+1,\p{1 \cdot \p{1 - \frac{x}{k}}^k}^{1/\p{k+1}} \leq \frac{1}{k+1}\p{1 + k \cdot \p{1 - \frac{x}{k}}} = 1 - \frac{x}{k+1},(1⋅(1−kx​)k)1/(k+1)≤k+11​(1+k⋅(1−kx​))=1−k+1x​,

    so for x∈[0,k]x \in \br{0, k}x∈[0,k],

    fk(x)−fk+1(x)=(1−xk)k−(1−xk+1)k+1≤1−xk+1−(1−xk+1)k+1.\begin{aligned} f_k\p{x} - f_{k+1}\p{x} &= \p{1 - \frac{x}{k}}^k - \p{1 - \frac{x}{k+1}}^{k+1} \\ &\leq 1 - \frac{x}{k+1} - \p{1 - \frac{x}{k+1}}^{k+1}. \end{aligned}fk​(x)−fk+1​(x)​=(1−kx​)k−(1−k+1x​)k+1≤1−k+1x​−(1−k+1x​)k+1.​

    Since 1−xk+1∈[0,1]1 - \frac{x}{k+1} \in \br{0, 1}1−k+1x​∈[0,1], we see fk(x)≤fk+1(x)f_k\p{x} \leq f_{k+1}\p{x}fk​(x)≤fk+1​(x) on [0,k]\br{0, k}[0,k]. On (k,k+1]\poc{k, k+1}(k,k+1], fk(x)=0f_k\p{x} = 0fk​(x)=0 but fk+1(x)≥0f_{k+1}\p{x} \geq 0fk+1​(x)≥0, and so fk≤fkf_k \leq f_kfk​≤fk​ everywhere. fk(x)→e−xf_k\p{x} \to e^{-x}fk​(x)→e−x, so by the monotone convergence theorem,

    lim⁡k→∞∫0kxn(1−xk)k dx=∫0∞lim⁡k→∞xnfk(x) dx=∫0∞xne−x dx=Γ(n+1)=n!.\lim_{k\to\infty} \int_0^k x^n\p{1 - \frac{x}{k}}^k \,\diff{x} = \int_0^\infty \lim_{k\to\infty} x^nf_k\p{x} \,\diff{x} = \int_0^\infty x^ne^{-x} \,\diff{x} = \Gamma\p{n+1} = n!.k→∞lim​∫0k​xn(1−kx​)kdx=∫0∞​k→∞lim​xnfk​(x)dx=∫0∞​xne−xdx=Γ(n+1)=n!.

  2. If k≥2k \geq 2k≥2, then

    (1+xk)−k≤(1+x2)−2∈L1([0,∞)).\p{1 + \frac{x}{k}}^{-k} \leq \p{1 + \frac{x}{2}}^{-2} \in L^1\p{\pco{0, \infty}}.(1+kx​)−k≤(1+2x​)−2∈L1([0,∞)).

    Thus, because ∣cos⁡xk∣≤1\abs{\cos\frac{x}{k}} \leq 1∣∣​coskx​∣∣​≤1, we may apply the dominated convergence theorem:

    lim⁡k→∞∫0∞(1+xk)−kcos⁡(xk) dx=∫0∞lim⁡k→∞(1+xk)−kcos⁡(xk) dx=∫0∞e−xcos⁡(0) dx=∫0∞e−x dx=1.\begin{aligned} \lim_{k\to\infty} \int_0^\infty \p{1 + \frac{x}{k}}^{-k} \cos\p{\frac{x}{k}} \,\diff{x} &= \int_0^\infty \lim_{k\to\infty} \p{1 + \frac{x}{k}}^{-k} \cos\p{\frac{x}{k}} \,\diff{x} \\ &= \int_0^\infty e^{-x} \cos\p{0} \,\diff{x} \\ &= \int_0^\infty e^{-x} \,\diff{x} \\ &= 1. \end{aligned}k→∞lim​∫0∞​(1+kx​)−kcos(kx​)dx​=∫0∞​k→∞lim​(1+kx​)−kcos(kx​)dx=∫0∞​e−xcos(0)dx=∫0∞​e−xdx=1.​
